p: Among the three Central African cities which were clearly outstanding in size before the 1930s (Kinshasa, Douala, and Brazzaville ( Figure 2A)) the first two (the proposed epicenters of HIV-1 groups M and O) had lower circumcision rates ( Figures 3A and 4A). During the period 1910–35, Libreville, Bangui, and Yaoundé may have had lower circumcision rates than after World War II, but we could not ascertain this by lack of adequate tables of ethnic composition. We did not include Rwandese and Burundian cities in our study, because they were very small up to mid 20 th century [65], and the cattle raising tradition of these countries makes bushmeat practice uncommon [93], [97], [98].
